To the Editor: Martha Weinman Lear and I grew up in Boston at about the same time. Her Boston in the 1950's was a ''consummately dull town.'' My Boston was enjoyable, stimulating; hers, it seems, insulated and insular.

Ms. Lear writes: ''When you and a date got out of the movies and it was too late to get a hamburger and too early to go home, the only thing left to do was to park on Memorial Drive, by the sweetly flowing Charles, for a deliciously agonizing hour of Please and No.''
But Ms. Lear was close to the Smith House and Howard Johnson, both serving good hamburgers, both overlooking the Charles.
Enjoying Billie Holiday, Stan Getz, Serge Challof, Pearl Bailey and good food at the Hi Hat, Columbus near Massachusetts Avenue, was hardly being deprived.

Sin in Scollay Square? I'm shocked. Shocked. The all-night movie next to Joe & Nemo's? Ladies of the evening? They had them at the Beacon and after-hours places (post 1 a.m. in Boston) serving whiskey in coffee cups.
Ms. Lear got it half right. It was Sally Keith, not Sally Rand, who twirled her tassels in opposite directions; Keith didn't do ''burlesque''; she twirled tassels. Sally Rand did feathered fans.
My Boston had no need to ''loosen up,'' ''become urbane.'' It was.
